    11	Whether you want to promote a car, a cola, a computer, a candidate, or your own career.
    12	
    13	Positioning is a concept that has changed the nature of advertising, a concept so simple, people have difficulty understanding how powerful it is.
    14	
    15	Every successful politician practices positioning. So do Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson.
    16	
    17	## Positioning defined
    18	
    19	Positioning starts with a product. A piece of merchandise, a service, a company, an institution, or even a person. Perhaps yourself.
    20	
    21	But positioning is not what you do to a product. Positioning is what you do to the mind of the prospect. That is, you position the product in the mind of the prospect.
    22	
    23	So it’s incorrect to call the concept “product positioning.” You’re not really doing something to the product itself.
    24	
    25	Not that positioning doesn’t involve change. It often does. But changes made in the name, the price, and the package are really not changes in the product at all. They’re basically cosmetic changes done for the purpose of securing a worthwhile position in the prospect’s mind.
    26	
    27	Positioning is the first body of thought that comes to grips with the difficult problem of getting heard in our overcommunicated society.
    28	
    29	## How positioning got started
    30	
    31	If one word can be said to have marked the course of advertising in the past decade, the word is “positioning.”
    32	
    33	Positioning has become a buzzword among advertising, sales, and marketing people. Not only in America, but around the world. Teachers, politicians, and editorial writers are using the word.
    34	
    35	Most people think positioning got started in 1972 when we wrote a series of articles entitled “The Positioning Era” for the trade paper *Advertising Age*.
    36	
    37	Since then, we have given more than 1000 speeches on positioning to advertising groups in 21 different countries around the world. And we have given away more than 150,000 copies of our “little orange booklet” which reprints the *Advertising Age* articles.

    13	The third largest? Whatever happened to those good old advertising words like “first” and “best” and “finest”?

    15	“Avis is only No. 2 in rent-a-cars, so why go with us? We try harder.”  
    16	“Seven-Up: the uncola.”  
    17	Along Madison Avenue, these are called positioning slogans. And the advertising people who write them spend their time and research money looking for positions, or holes, in the marketplace.  
    18	But positioning has stirred up interest well beyond Madison Avenue. With good reason.  
    19	Anyone can use positioning strategy to get ahead in the game of life. And look at it this way: If you don’t understand and use the principles, your competitors undoubtedly will.

    20	Poetic? Yes. Artful? Yes. But also a straightforward, clearly defined

    34

    39	If you spend $1 million a year on advertising, you are bombarding the

    16	The essence of positioning is sacrifice. You must be willing to give up something in order to establish that unique position.

    18	The focus of most marketing operations is just the opposite. They look for ways to broaden their markets by line extension, by size and flavor proliferation, by multiple distribution. All these things tend to produce short-term sales increases and long-term positioning erosion.  
    19	In positioning, smaller may be better. It is usually better to look for smaller targets that you can own exclusively rather than a bigger market you have to share with three or four other brands.  
    20	You can’t be all things to all people and still have a powerful position.
    21	
    22	## You need patience  
    23	Very few companies can afford to launch a new product on a nationwide scale.  
    24	Instead they look for places to make the brand successful. And then roll it out to other markets.  
    25	The geographic roll-out is one way. You build the product in one market and then move on to another. From east to west. Or vice versa.  
    26	The demographic roll-out is another. Philip Morris built Marlboro into the No. 1 cigarette on college campuses long before it became the No. 1 brand nationwide.  
    27	The chronologic roll-out is the third way. You build the brand among a specific age group and then roll it out to others. “The Pepsi Generation” helped Pepsi-Cola build the product among the younger set and then reap the benefits as they grew up.

     5	**Original File**: data/raw_documents/Positioning_The_Battle_for_Your_Mind.pdf
     6	**Page Number**: 11/182
     7	**Processing Time**: 2026-02-06T17:09:02.229851
     8	
     9	---
    10	
    11	# New Foreword to the Marketing Classic
    12	
    13	I began to realize some years ago that important steps needed to precede the four Ps. All good marketing planning must start with R, Research, before any of the Ps can be set.
    14	
    15	Research reveals, among other things, that customers differ greatly in their needs, perceptions, and preferences. Therefore, customers must be classified into S, Segments.
    16	
    17	Most companies cannot serve all segments. A company must choose the segment that they can serve at a superior level. This is T, Targeting.
    18	
    19	Now there is one more step before 4P planning can take place. That is P, Positioning. This is the revolutionary concept that Al Ries and Jack Trout introduced in their now classic book, *Positioning*.
    20	
    21	Positioning is a revolutionary idea precisely because it cuts across the other four Ps. It informs each of the Ps and adds consistency to them. Ever since the 1972 series of *Advertising Age* articles on the subject by the two authors of this book, the discipline of marketing has never been the same.
    22	
    23	Positioning can affect the product. Volvo’s conscious decision to build safety features into its product set up the hugely successful “safety” position for the Volvo brand. In the process, a small company from Sweden became one of the world’s most powerful automobile brands. (And commanded a big price when the company was bought by Ford.)
    24	
    25	Positioning can affect the price of the product. Häagen-Dazs’s conscious decision to introduce a more expensive line of ice cream set up the “premium” ice cream position for the brand and made Häagen-Dazs one of the enduring marketing successes of the past several decades. (What Häagen-Dazs did at the high end, brands like Wal-Mart and Southwest Airlines did at the low end.)
    26	
    27	Positioning can affect the place the product is sold. Hanes, the leading department store brand of panty hose, developed a panty hose product specifically for supermarket distribution. The brand was called L’eggs and it was packaged in an eggshaped container. The “supermarket” panty hose position made the L’eggs brand an enormous success and ultimately the largest-selling panty hose brand in the country.

1	# Page 12
     2	
     3	**Document Title**: Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind
     4	**Author**: Al Ries, Jack Trout
     5	**Original File**: data/raw_documents/Positioning_The_Battle_for_Your_Mind.pdf
     6	**Page Number**: 12/182
     7	**Processing Time**: 2026-02-06T17:09:02.229961
     8	
     9	---
    10	
    11	Positioning can affect the promotion of the product. Little Caesars became a powerful pizza brand by elevating its “two for the price of one” promotion into a positioning strategy. Their “pizza, pizza” refrain became one of the most memorable advertising programs ever run and made the Little Caesars brand into the fastest-growing pizza chain.  
    12	Then, of course, Little Caesars dropped their “two-for-one” strategy and sales fell apart, an event that demonstrates not only the power of positioning, but also the difficulty of changing one’s position after it is established.  
    13	Marketing is not a static discipline. Marketing is a constantly changing discipline and positioning is one of those revolutionary changes that keeps the marketing field alive, interesting, exciting, and fascinating.  
    14	When you read this seminal book on the subject I think you will find that positioning is not only alive and well today, but also a powerful tool for creating and maintaining real differentiation in the marketplace.
    15	
    16	> Philip Kotler, Ph.D.  
    17	> *Kellogg Graduate School of Management*  
    18	> *Northwestern University* How often have you heard that bromide?

      "key_entities": [

        "Abby Rand",
        "James Brady",
        "Aspen",
        "Kitzbühel"
      ]
    },

      "title": "Positioning the Catholic Church",
      "pages": "154-158",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Identity crisis after internal reform",
        "Repositioning institutions",
        "The complexity vs. simplicity trap"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "The authors analyze the post-Vatican II identity crisis of the Catholic Church. Historically positioned as the 'Teacher of the Law' (rules/rigidity), the Church's shift toward flexibility left the laity confused, leading to a decline in attendance. Retracing the Church's 2,000-year history suggested a more fundamental and modern position: 'Teacher of the Word' (relating Christ’s teachings to contemporary problems). However, the Church’s leadership resisted this 'obvious' solution, favoring complex, multi-role definitions that failed to resolve the core communication problem.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Catholic Church",
        "Vatican II",
        "Avery Dulles",
        "Peter Berger"
      ]
    },
    {

        "Strategic name selection"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "Personal success is often driven more by external 'horses' than by raw internal effort. The chapter identifies six 'horses' to ride for career advancement: the Company (choose a growth industry), the Boss (hitch your wagon to a star), a Friend (business connections), an Idea (champion the 'obvious' but controversial), Faith (believing in others' visions), and Yourself (the hardest horse to ride). The authors also emphasize the importance of having the 'right' name and avoiding 'initialitus' or common names that cause confusion in the corporate mind.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Ray Kroc",
        "McDonald brothers",
        "John Wayne",
        "Ty Cobb",
        "Winston Churchill"
      ]
    },
    {
      "chapter": 24,
      "title": "Positioning Your Business",
      "pages": "167-173",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Six diagnostic questions",
        "Outside-in thinking",
        "The role of objectivity"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "A successful positioning program starts by asking: (1) What position do you own? (2) What position do you want to own? (3) Whom must you outgun? (4) Do you have enough money? (5) Can you stick it out? (6) Do you match your position? The authors argue that 'creativity' is often the enemy of strategy; instead, creativity must be subordinated to the positioning objective. Furthermore, they stress the value of 'outsiders' (like ad agencies) who provide the essential objectivity needed to see what is actually in the prospect's mind.",
      "key_entities": [

        "Nyquil",
        "Procter & Gamble",
        "Avis"
      ]
    },
    {
      "chapter": 25,
      "title": "Playing the Positioning Game",
      "pages": "174-182",
      "core_concepts": [
        "General semantics (words don't have meanings, people do)",
        "Mental flexibility",
        "The rule of 'Never go head-to-head'"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "The final chapter outlines the mindset required for positioning mastery: vision, courage, objectivity, simplicity, and sacrifice. Success requires understanding that words are mere triggers for meanings already in the mind. The 'essence of positioning is sacrifice'—narrowing one's focus (like Nyquil giving up the daytime market) to own a specific niche. Above all, the 'first rule' of the game is to never compete head-on against an established leader; instead, find an open position near the center of the market or reposition the competitor.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Alfred Korzybski",
        "Volkswagen/Audi",
        "IBM",
        "Xerox",

}

Sections:
1. New Foreword (Page 11-12)
2. Introduction (Page 13-15)
3. Chapter 1: What Positioning Is All About (Page 16-19)
4. Chapter 2: The Assault on the Mind (Page 20-26)
5. Chapter 3: Getting Into the Mind (Page 27-34)

Return a JSON-like structure with summaries for each.

{
  "summaries": [
    {
      "section": "New Foreword (Page 11-12)",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Positioning as the precursor to the 4 Ps (Product, Price, Place, Promotion)",
        "The Marketing Sequence: Research -> Segmentation -> Targeting -> Positioning -> 4 Ps",
        "Consistency through Positioning"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "Philip Kotler argues that positioning is a revolutionary concept because it informs and unifies all other marketing activities. It is the final strategic step before tactical planning (the 4 Ps) and is essential for creating real differentiation. Once a position is established in the mind, it is extremely difficult to change.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Philip Kotler",
        "Volvo (Safety position)",
        "Häagen-Dazs (Premium position)",
        "L’eggs (Supermarket distribution position)",
        "Little Caesars (Two-for-one position)"
      ]
    },
    {
      "section": "Introduction (Page 13-15)",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Overcommunicated society",
        "Positioning defined: What you do to the mind of the prospect",
        "Comparatives vs. Superlatives"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "The fundamental problem today is not a lack of communication, but communication itself. In an overcommunicated society, the mind rejects most messages. Positioning is the first body of thought to address this by focusing on the 'receiving end' rather than the 'sending end.' Modern success requires finding 'holes' in the mind rather than claiming to be the 'best.'",
      "key_entities": [
        "Avis (No. 2 positioning)",
        "Seven-Up (The uncola)",
        "Sanka (Third largest-selling coffee)"
      ]
    },
    {
      "section": "Chapter 1: What Positioning Is All About (Page 16-19)",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Return to reality",
        "The Oversimplified Mind & Message",
        "Perception as Reality",
        "Outside-In Perspective"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "To be successful, one must touch base with the reality already present in the prospect's mind. Positioning does not create something new but manipulates existing connections. Because the mind is a 'dripping sponge' that cannot absorb more information, messages must be sharpened and simplified. Strategy is no longer about the product's truth, but the prospect's perception of it.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Miller Lite",
        "John Lindsay (Perception is reality)"
      ]
    },
    {
      "section": "Chapter 2: The Assault on the Mind (Page 20-26)",
      "core_concepts": [
        "Sensory Overload",
        "Transmission Traffic Jam",
        "Media, Product, and Advertising Explosions"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "The sheer volume of communication (books, newsprint, TV, paper, products) has created a mental traffic jam. As advertising effectiveness decreases due to this clutter, the volume of advertising paradoxically increases. This 'assault' forces the brain to go blank beyond a certain point of sensation, making it nearly impossible for traditional messages to penetrate.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Mr. Clean (High recognition through simplicity)",
        "George Bush (Low recognition despite high visibility)",
        "Chevrolet (Confusion caused by too many models)",
        "The New York Times (Information volume example)"
      ]
    },
    {
      "section": "Chapter 3: Getting Into the Mind (Page 27-34)",
      "core_concepts": [
        "The Law of the First",
        "The Product Era vs. Image Era vs. Positioning Era",
        "The Lindbergh Lesson"
      ],
      "main_arguments": "The easiest way to get into the mind is to be first; second is 'nowhere.' Advertising has evolved from focusing on product features (Product Era) to brand reputation (Image Era) and finally to mental strategy (Positioning Era). To penetrate the mind today, one must subtract the 'poetry' and 'creativity' and deliver a purified, simplified message that accounts for competitors.",
      "key_entities": [
        "Charles Lindbergh (First to fly solo across the North Atlantic)",
        "Neil Armstrong (First on the moon)",
        "IBM (First to position 'computer')",
        "Amerigo Vespucci (Successful positioning vs. Columbus)",
        "Michelob (First premium domestic beer position)",
        "Miller Lite (Purified message)",
        "Beck’s Beer (Positioning against Lowenbrau)"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

{
  "structure": [
    {
      "title": "New Foreword to the Marketing Classic",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_11.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_12.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Philip Kotler argues that positioning is a revolutionary concept because it informs and unifies all other marketing activities (Product, Price, Place, Promotion). It is the final strategic step after Research, Segmentation, and Targeting, and is essential for creating real differentiation. Key examples include Volvo (Safety), Häagen-Dazs (Premium), and L’eggs (Distribution).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Introduction",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_13.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_15.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Defines positioning as 'what you do to the mind of the prospect.' In an overcommunicated society, communication itself is the problem. Success requires finding 'holes' in the mind. Mentions the shift from superlatives (best, finest) to comparatives (Avis is No. 2, 7-Up is the Uncola).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 1: What Positioning Is All About",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_16.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_19.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Emphasizes a 'return to reality.' Positioning manipulates existing mental connections rather than creating something new. Messages must be simplified to penetrate the oversimplified mind. Core argument: Perception is reality.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 2: The Assault on the Mind",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_20.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_26.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Explores the impact of sensory overload and the explosion of media and products. As advertising effectiveness decreases, volume increases, leading to a mental 'traffic jam.' Simple messages like 'Mr. Clean' succeed where complex ones fail.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 3: Getting Into the Mind",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_27.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_34.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "The 'Law of the First': being first is the easiest way to enter the mind (e.g., Lindbergh, IBM). Discusses the evolution from the Product Era to the Image Era and finally the Positioning Era. Strategy focuses on the receiving end of communication.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 4: Those Little Ladders in Your Head",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_35.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_40.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Introduces 'Product Ladders' as mental ranking systems. Successful positioning relates a brand to existing rungs. Mentions the 'Rule of Seven' and the power of 'against' positions (Avis vs. Hertz) and the 'Uncola' strategy (7-Up).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 5: You Can’t Get There from Here",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_41.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_45.md",
      "start_line_index": 12,
      "summary_context": "Warns against head-on attacks on market leaders. Some positions are unattainable regardless of budget (e.g., RCA/GE vs. IBM in computers). Success requires finding a unique angle based on existing strengths (e.g., NCR in retail).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 6: Positioning of a Leader",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_46.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_53.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Leaders must reinforce their original category concept ('The Real Thing') and 'cover all bets' by adopting new technologies or multibrand strategies (e.g., P&G). Leadership is about getting into the mind first and staying there.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 7: Positioning of a Follower",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_54.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_60.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Followers must find an 'open hole' or 'creneau' (size, price, sex, age) rather than copying leaders. Examples include the VW Beetle (size) and Marlboro (masculinity). Warns against the 'everybody trap' and 'factory creneaus.'",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 8: Repositioning the Competition",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_61.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_68.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "When no creneau exists, create one by dislodging a competitor's idea. Differs from comparative advertising; requires changing the consumer's view of the competitor. Key examples: Tylenol vs. Aspirin, Stolichnaya vs. US-made 'Russian' vodkas.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 9: The Power of the Name",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_69.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_79.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "The name is the primary hook for positioning. Ideally, names should describe the product benefit (Head & Shoulders). Coined names (Kodak) work only for first-in-category brands. Obsolete names must be addressed (Standard Oil to Exxon).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 10: The No-Name Trap",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_80.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_88.md",
      "start_line_index": 12,
      "summary_context": "Argues against the use of initials for lesser-known companies. While IBM and GE succeed with initials, for others it is 'corporate suicide' because the mind works aurally and initials lack descriptive power.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 11: The Free-Ride Trap",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_89.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_93.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Capitalizing on an established brand for a new product (Alka-Seltzer Plus) often leads to 'Teeter-Totter' dilution. A single name cannot represent two distinct products. New products need new names and new mental ladders.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 12: The Line-Extension Trap",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_94.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_104.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Critiques 'inside-out' thinking where manufacturers assume brand reputation carries over. Consumers view brands as product surrogates (Bayer = Aspirin). Extension blurs identity. One exception is 'broadening the base' (Johnson's Baby Shampoo for adults).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 13: When Line Extension Can Work",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_105.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_113.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Line extension offers short-term recognition but long-term mental blurring. Provides 'Rules of the Road': use house names for low-volume commodities with small budgets, and new names for high-volume breakthrough products.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 14: Positioning a Company: Xerox",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_114.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_122.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Corporate positioning affects talent and investors. Xerox failed in office systems because it is mentally locked to 'copiers.' Proposed 'third-leg' strategy: AT&T (communication), IBM (processing), Xerox (output/Lasography).",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 15: Positioning a Country: Belgium",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_123.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_127.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Countries need 'mental picture postcards.' Belgium succeeded by positioning itself as a destination ('five Amsterdams') using Michelin ratings, rather than a gateway. Strategy requires long-term commitment.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 16: Positioning an Island: Jamaica",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_128.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_131.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Jamaica differentiated itself from 'sand and surf' by positioning as 'The Hawaii of the Caribbean.' Leverages existing mental images of Hawaii's prestige and topography to attract closer US travelers.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 17: Positioning a Product: Milk Duds",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_132.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_134.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Milk Duds repositioned the candy bar category as 'fast-disappearing' and positioned itself as the 'long-lasting alternative.' Leveraged the value-conscious 10-year-old candy buyer's mindset. Sales hit record highs.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 18: Positioning a Service: Mailgram",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_135.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_139.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Services are verbal/radio-oriented. Mailgram succeeded by positioning as a 'low-cost Telegram' rather than a 'high-speed letter,' leveraging Western Union's existing mental equity. Consistency is key; changing strategy caused volume decline.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 19: Positioning a Long Island Bank",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_140.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_147.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Long Island Trust fought NYC bank 'invasion' by owning the local 'helping Long Island' position. Framing outsiders as 'city banks' improved local perception across all metrics, even where competitors were objectively stronger.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 20: Positioning a New Jersey Bank",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_148.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_151.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "United Jersey positioned as 'The Fast-Moving Bank' against 'Lethargic National Banks.' Aligned operations (decentralization, ATMs) with marketing promise. Resulted in 26% profit increase and improved morale.",
      "children": []
    },
    {
      "title": "Chapter 21: Positioning a ski resort: Stowe",
      "level": 1,
      "start_page_id": "page_152.md",
      "end_page_id": "page_153.md",
      "start_line_index": 11,
      "summary_context": "Leveraged authority/expert credibility (Abby Rand's Top 10 list) to position Stowe as 'The Ski Capital of the East.' Created a mental 'reward' for New Yorkers to travel further to a world-class destination.",
      "children": []
    },
    {

content.text:
Global Map successfully generated and saved to `global_map.json`.

The document structure was thoroughly analyzed, mapping the 182-page marketing classic *Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind* by Al Ries and Jack Trout. 

### Key Structural Findings:
- **Core Framework**: The document follows a sequential structure from a New Foreword by Philip Kotler and an Introduction through 25 chapters that detail the evolution and application of positioning strategy.
- **Verification**: Each section's start page and exact line number were verified against the raw markdown content. For example, Chapter 1 begins on Page 16, while Chapter 25 concludes on Page 182.
- **Contextualization**: Each entry in the map includes a detailed summary capturing key concepts (e.g., "The Law of the First," "Product Ladders," "The Free-Ride Trap") and critical entities (e.g., IBM, Xerox, Avis, 7-Up).
- **Continuity**: The map ensures 100% coverage of the document, with `end_page_id` values connecting each section to the next without gaps.

The resulting `global_map.json` is now ready for use in constructing a detailed Knowledge Graph or for targeted retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) tasks.
